title: Project Cyclops
author: Hoover, Thomas, 1941-

quoteFirst: It is generally the custom in the navy to strike the bell sixteen times at midnight on New Year's eve--eight bells for the old year and eight bells for the new! Of course with us this custom was rigidly adhered to; but not only did we strike sixteen bells at _our_ midnight, but we also struck the same number at
quoteLast: , which, allowing for the exact difference in time, would be midnight in England, so that we had at least the satisfaction of knowing that our bell was being employed in the same way as many others in the navy at the same time.
title: The Great Frozen Sea: A Personal Narrative of the Voyage of the "Alert"
author: Markham, Albert Hastings, Sir, 1841-1918

quoteFirst: Being in ballast, she lay over at an angle that would have alarmed anybody but a yachtsman; but she was a staunch, weatherly old ship, and hung well to windward. It was my wheel from
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: , and as I wrestled with it in the attempt to keep the old barky up to her work, I suddenly caught sight of the gaunt form of a crane flapping her heavy wings in dogged fashion to come up with us from to leeward, we making at the time about eight knots an hour.

quoteFirst: Sometimes my games got me in trouble, and once I was badly injured. On the “dog watches” from four to six and
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: s, both watches were on deck and I didn’t have to keep quiet so they could sleep. It was then that I ran the decks, careless of the thudding noise my feet made; or I sang chanteys loud and long at the top of my voice.
title: The cradle of the deep
author: Lowell, Joan, 1900-1967; Wiese, Kurt, 1887-1974 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: In the dog-watches of the evening, after supper, from
quoteLast: , the blue-jacket is given his leisure. It is then that pipes are smoked, vigilance relaxed, boxing and wrestling bouts are in order, and Jacky settles down for his rest after the day of labor.

quoteLast: , large numbers to N.W. Dec. 8th, 10 a.m., flock to W.S.W. At Hanois L.H., Aug. 14th, o.m., N., Goldcrests, some killed.

quoteFirst: Very soon Pat Francis dropped off De Molay Four, slowing at Elcho, ran straight to the operator for his order, signed it and at once Order 79 was throbbing back to young Giddings at Medicine Bend. It was precisely
quoteLast: when Giddings gave back the Complete and at 7.55 Elcho reported Special 326, "out," all just like clockwork. What a head Martin Duffy has, thought young Giddings--and behold! all the complicated everlasting headwork of the trick and the day, and of the West End and its honor, was now up to the signature of Third Eighty at Rat River.
title: Held for Orders: Being Stories of Railroad Life
author: Spearman, Frank H. (Frank Hamilton), 1859-1937; Hambidge, Jay, 1867-1924 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , as we have no candles we have a spelling game, each one in turn adding a letter that continues to spell a word. The object is to avoid saying the last letter of the word, and consequently the words changed or lengthened in an extraordinary fashion.

quoteFirst: No doubt the enemy, from photographs by his airmen, imagines them to be more important than they really are. He is faced by our machine-guns and rifles along the whole line. From
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: he returns to the charge with a tenacity and vigour which it is only fair to acknowledge. He wants to break through at all costs. All his efforts are in vain.
